headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Time Warner Inc. Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Rob, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to
componenttext:
Welcome to the Time Warner Inc. Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Rob, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] 
Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to Jessica Holscott, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. Holscott, you may now begin.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Rob, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Time Warner's Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. First, we refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly co
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Rob, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Time Warner's Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. 
First, we refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release and trending schedules. These reconciliations are available in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Second, today's announcement includes certain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectations. Actual results may vary materially from those expressed or those implied by these statements. Please see our 10-K and 10-Q for items that could affect future results or performance. 
I'll now turn the call over to Jeff Bewkes, Time Warner's Chairman and CEO, who will be followed by Howard Averill, Time Warner's CFO. And after their prepared remarks, our divisional CEOs, John Martin, Richard Plepler and Kevin Tsujihara, and our General Counsel, Paul Cappuccio, will join us for our Q&A session. Jeff?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica, and thanks, everybody, for listening in this morning. We had an outstanding fourth quarter, capping off a very successful year in 2016. And for the year, our revenues increased 4% to $29.3 billion and adjusted operating income grew 10%
componenttext:
Thanks, Jessica, and thanks, everybody, for listening in this morning. 
We had an outstanding fourth quarter, capping off a very successful year in 2016. And for the year, our revenues increased 4% to $29.3 billion and adjusted operating income grew 10% to $7.6 billion with record results in each of our divisions. 
Adjusted EPS was up 23% to $5.86 per share. That's our eighth consecutive year of double-digit growth in adjusted EPS. 
Now looking at the fourth quarter. Revenues grew 11% to $7.9 billion with increases in each of our divisions and adjusted operating income increased 25% to $1.8 billion. 
We generated a record $4.4 billion in free cash flow, and we returned close to $3.6 billion to shareholders in share repurchases and dividends over the course of the year. 
What's driving these results is the same combination of strong execution, continued investment in our businesses and disciplined capital allocation that's enabled us to provide superior long-term returns to our shareholders. 
Our strategy starts, as you'll know, with investing in creating the world's most compelling video content. We then ensure that it can be accessed and enjoyed by consumers wherever, whenever and on whatever device they want it all around the world. And increasingly, that means working with both our distribution partners and on our own to ensure great experiences that connect consumers with our content and our brands. You can see the success of this strategy across each of our businesses last year. 
Let me share a few highlights to start off on [ph] that one. In 2016, Turner made terrific progress on its goal of transforming its leading portfolio of entertainment, news, sports and kids brands, investing in each of its businesses to make them ever more powerful and engaging for audiences. 
For the year, among adults 18 to 49 in prime time, we held 3 of the top 5 slots among ad-supported cable networks with TBS, TNT and Adult Swim. And in fact, TBS was the #1 entertainment network in prime for the fourth consecutive year, showcasing a great mix of fresh originals, sports and acquired content. 
Early last year, we began introducing a lineup of bold, new comedies that includes Angie Tribeca, The Detour and Wrecked. We've also had a breakout success in Full Frontal with Samantha Bee, which, during the summer, began outpacing The Daily Show and continued to do so in the fourth quarter. We also added 2 new comedies in People of Earth and Search Party, which debuted to strong critical reviews. All of the freshman shows have been renewed. And if you haven't seen them, we've made the entire seasons available on demand to binge view, as all the latest Turner original series, all on demand. 
Now if 2016 was TBS's year, we expect 2017 to belong to TNT. It's just on the [ph] way in its refresh process, but it's already off to an encouraging start with newcomers Animal Kingdom produced by Warner Bros. and Good Behavior, both of which have also been renewed. 
And this year, we're rolling out a slate that includes exciting, new series like The Alienist, Real and Klos, adding compelling franchise movies, which include those from the DC Universe and the entire Star Wars library and recent Marvel movies and you can see why we're very confident in TNT's future as the home for great [indiscernible]. 
Another part of Turner's success, a critical part and, well, basically a vital part, is our success in sports. And our rights to the NCAA tournament, the NBA and Major League Baseball. Last year, we had the NCAA Men's Basketball Championship game for the first time ever, and we generated record revenues across our March Madness properties. This is such a strong relationship for us that we, along with CBS, renewed our deal with the NCAA through 2032. Our NBA package also continues to deliver tremendous results, and that was highlighted by Game 7 of last year's -- last season's Western Conference Finals, which became the most watched telecast ever in the history of TNT. We also launched our ELEAGUE gaming network in partnership with WME | IMG, and that's off to a promising start and it's already bringing new, younger viewers to TBS. 
Speaking of younger viewers, I have to mention Adult Swim again and its leading position with millennial audiences. In 2016, it was the #1 network among 18- to 34-year-olds for the 12th year in a row. 
Now what a year for CNN, the #1 news network among adults 18 to 49 in prime time. Let's just say that again, the #1 news network among adults 18 to 49 at prime time and the #1 digital news destination in 2016. CNN capped off its most watched year ever with a record-setting election night to rank #1 in prime at evening across all cable and broadcast networks. 
With the historic U.S. Presidential election behind us and the new administration in place, we have every confidence that CNN will continue to reinforce its reputation as not only the source of the world [indiscernible] for trusted news coverage but also as the destination for compelling original series and documentaries. 
And international, Turner launched a dozen new networks while holding its position as the #1 portfolio of pay TV networks across Latin America. 
Whether it's content, advertising or distribution, Turner is making important progress evolving its business in ways that recognize changing media habits and [indiscernible] to consumer first. 
Last year, Turner continued to build on the successful 2015 launches of short-form news site, Great Big Story, and digital studio, Super Deluxe. And in November, Turner Classic Movies launched FilmStruck, a new over-the-top service for lovers of art house movies. 
And in distribution, Turner has demonstrated the value of its portfolio by being an anchor tenant on each of the new virtual MVPD services that have launched as well as on Hulu's upcoming new service. 
Now let's move to the gold standard in premium video, Home Box Office. HBO had another great year while making investments for an even stronger original programming lineup. 
Once again, 2016 brought more Primetime Emmy Awards to HBO than any other network, and that's for the 15th straight year. Game of Thrones' sixth season hit record viewership of 26 million people per episode. That's about a 50 rating on HBO, actually more than that on the subbase. And we also had the biggest launch of a new series in HBO history with Westworld. It's produced by Warner Bros. and it's surpassed even the Game of Thrones' first season. I want to pause on that and say that even with the explosion of new outlets and choices in this golden age of video, HBO remains singular in its ability to attract [indiscernible]  who push the boundaries of what's creatively possible. And that's the case whether it's on an epic scale of a show like Westworld or on a human scale with a show like Girls, which begins its sixth and final season this weekend. You'll also see that in our upcoming limited series, Big Little Lies, with a stellar cast including Nicole Kidman and Reese Witherspoon, which follows last year's acclaimed series, The Night Of. 
In 2016 at HBO, we also premiered the well-received fresh from seasons of Insecure, Divorce, Vice Principals and High Maintenance. And those ran alongside returning comedy powerhouses Veep, Silicon Valley and Ballers. 
Of course, HBO offers much more than its original programming. It's got the best lineup of recent Hollywood films, hit bounds available anywhere. And they account for a significant amount of HBO's viewership. 
When you add in great documentaries, sports and late-night powerhouses like Last Week Tonight with John Oliver or Real Time with Bill Maher, both of which experienced record viewership last year, as well as our new nightly series, VICE News Tonight, you can see why HBO stands out from the pack and why we're very confident about the growth opportunities ahead. 
HBO has also been blazing the trail and connecting with consumers through its streaming product, which added distribution on Microsoft's Xbox, on Samsung's smart TVs, Sony's PlayStation and Amazon Prime Channels in 2016. 
In total, HBO recently surpassed 2 million domestic over-the-top subscribers. So we're really pleased with the progress. 
And HBO is just as focused on reaching consumers abroad with over-the-top launches in Spain, Brazil and Argentina in 2016. 
Finally, let's turn to Warner Bros., the global entertainment leader. Warner has had another record year with strong results in television and film and a growing consumer products business that ties into its focus on franchise properties. 
In movies, we reached nearly $5 billion in global box office. That's the second best year in our history. And it was driven across a range of hits led by our franchise releases: Batman v Superman, Suicide Squad and Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them. But the depth and diversity of our slate was also on display with strong performances from movies like Central Intelligence, Lights Out, The Conjuring 2 and Sully.  We are just as excited about 2017 with a lineup that starts with the LEGO Batman Movie, which opened, by the way, this weekend, and we also have the highly anticipated next installments in our DC slate with Wonder Woman in June and Justice League in November. 
In television at Warner's, we were the #1 supplier to broadcast networks again. This is now for the eighth year in a row with at least 4 shows on each network this season. And that includes the #1 overall series on television, The Big Bang Theory, and the #1 non-scripted series on television, The Voice, as well as newcomers like Lethal Weapon and Riverdale. 
We've mentioned before that our DC franchise has been one of our most important priorities at Warner's, and you can see the results not just at the box office but also in the 10 DC-based shows we have on TV; in the 4.5 billion consumer spend on DC merchandise last year, contributing to our record performance in consumer products; and finally in our hit video game franchises, including Injustice 2, which were released this coming May. 
Similar to Turner and HBO, Warner Bros. also continues to make strides in developing direct-to-consumer capabilities to serve its fans in today's evolving environment. We created the Warner Bros. digital network division, and we closed deals to buy [indiscernible], giving us a platform to connect to coveted and hard to reach young gamers and DramaFever, which gives us the capability to launch and operate new over-the-top broadband VOD services. 
Across our company, we had a very active and successful year and we're  inspired by the future of media that we're to shape. As we've said many times before, connecting more directly with consumers as our businesses evolve, both within and outside the existing ecosystem is one of our most important strategic priorities, and we're making a lot of progress. 
We believe our deal to be acquired by AT&T, which we announced on October 22, will further enhance our ability to innovate and thrive. The special meeting of shareholders to vote on the transaction will be held a week from today. The regulatory review process is underway, and we remain confident that the deal will be approved later this year. Once that happens, we're very excited about the potential of combining AT&T's great strength in mobile and video distribution, and its fantastic customer relationships with the world's greatest storytelling. And the value we can create together by accelerating the evolution of our company and our industries for the benefit of consumers. 
In the meantime, we remain very confident in our ability to continue to lead the industry both creatively and financially, not just for 2017, but for many years to come. 
Thanks, again, for listening. And with that, let me turn it over to Howard.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning. I'll begin by referring to the first slide of the presentation, which is now available on our website. Starting with consolidated results. We finished 2016 with a great fourth quarter. Revenues increased 11%, adjusted ope
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning. I'll begin by referring to the first slide of the presentation, which is now available on our website. 
Starting with consolidated results. We finished 2016 with a great fourth quarter. Revenues increased 11%, adjusted operating income was up a very strong 25% with growth across all divisions and adjusted EPS grew 18%. 
We also had strong results for the full year, with revenue up 4%, adjusted operating income up 10% at each of our division posted record profits, leading to our eighth consecutive year of double-digit growth in adjusted EPS. 
Margins expanded over 100 basis points for the year even as we increased our investment in content and marketing across the company to over $15 billion, and we continue to remain focused on tightening and managing overhead cost and operating efficiently to help fund these investments. 
Adjusted EPS increased 23% to $5.86 for the year, which included a $0.29 net tax benefit related to a tax accounting method change that we recognized in the third quarter. Excluding the tax benefit, adjusted EPS would have increased a robust 17% to $5.57 led by our strong operating performance as well as a lower share count. 
In 2016, we repurchased $2.3 billion of our stock prior to discontinuing share repurchases in October as a result of the pending merger with AT&T. And combined with our dividend, we returned close to $3.6 billion to shareholders during the year. So we delivered strong financial results in 2016 while continuing to make investments across our businesses to sustain attractive growth over the long term. And we expect to carry that momentum into 2017. 
Looking ahead, in order to better reflect our operating performance and given the volatility in certain below-the-line items that impact our adjusted EPS, we are providing 2017 guidance for adjusted operating income, which we expect will grow in the high single digits based on current exchange rates. I'll provide more context on the key drivers across our businesses throughout my presentation. 
Now turning to the segments. I'll start at Turner, where we closed out a record year with another quarter of strong profit growth as we continue to benefit from our domestic affiliate renewals. 
Subscription revenues increased 14% in the fourth quarter and was up 12% to the year, including 150 basis point FX headwind. Domestic subscription revenues grew 15% in the quarter, and we finished 2016 up over 14%, on the higher end of what we expected coming into the year. So we're really pleased with the upcome of our affiliate renewals, and we remain confident in our outlook for solid, double-digit domestic subscription revenue growth in 2017. 
International subscription revenue was up in the high single digits in the quarter, and that included a 300 basis points drag from FX. Advertising revenue was down 2% in the fourth quarter, that was a bit below our expectations because of a slowdown in certain international regions. As a result, international advertising declined mid-single digits excluding about a 350 basis points drag from FX. However, we still believe secular trends internationally remains strong. 
Domestically, we face a 300 basis point headwind from the comparison to last year's record Major League Baseball post season a performance. Even so, advertising was flat in the quarter. That capped off a strong year for domestic advertising, which increased mid-single digits. The growth was led by the record performance at our news business as it benefited from the presidential election coverage as well as healthy demand for our premium sports properties. 
Looking at the first quarter. We expect total advertising revenue to be flat to up low single digits. The scatter market remains healthy with pricing up double digits versus the upfront at our domestic entertainment networks, and we expect our sports and news businesses to be the key drivers and international trends to improve. 
Moving on. Turner's strong revenue trends resulted in adjusted operating income growth of 9% in the fourth quarter and 8% for the year. And we achieved that while continuing to make significant investments at programming, marketing and new digital initiatives. 
Programming expenses were flat in the fourth quarter and up low single digits excluding programming charges from both periods. For the full year, programming was up 5%, primarily related to higher sports costs and CNN's election coverage. 
Marketing cost increased around 20% both for the quarter and the year as we invested in the rebrands at TNT and TBS including support for our new original series. 
Overall, Turner delivered great financial results in 2016 and has a lot of operating momentum. And with the strength of our brands in the investments we're making across the business, we believe we are very well positioned to continue delivering attractive growth for the long term. 
Turning now to HBO, where our investments and high-quality programming contributed to double-digit profit growth in the fourth quarter and have positioned HBO to capitalize on the big global opportunity for subscription services. Domestic subscription revenue was up in the mid-single digits for the quarter and the year. 
Similar to recent quarters, we continue to see subscriber headwinds at our traditional affiliates, especially those involved in M&A integration. As a result, despite very strong growth in digital subscribers, total domestic subs across HBO and Cinemax were essentially flat for the year. 
Looking forward, we believe HBO has a big untapped subscriber opportunity in the U.S. and capitalizing on that is our most important long-term growth driver. So the deals we recently signed, we're emphasizing subscriber growth. That means as our partners grow HBO subs, it will benefit our subscription revenue growth. And while it takes time to implement new deals, we're very encouraged with the initial progress on the deals we've closed. However, finishing this affiliate cycles has taken longer than anticipated, and we're still in the midst of removing some deals. So we do not expect sequential improvement in subscription revenue growth in the first quarter. But we do anticipate that sub-revenue trends will improve as the year progresses, especially in the second half of 2017 as we complete a period of negotiations and continue to expand our digital distribution. We've seen a nice pickup in OTT sub-growth recently, and our goal is to add more digital partners later this year. Along with the return to subscriber growth in our traditional business, that should contribute to a solid increase in total subs for the year. And taking all these factors into account, we anticipate high single digit growth in subscription revenue for the year. 
Moving on. Content and other revenues were up 7% for the quarter, mainly due to higher home video revenue. For the year, content and other revenues grew 2%, primarily reflecting healthy growth in international licensing as demand for HBO's original content remains robust. 
Across HBO's international networks including unconsolidated JVs, revenues were up double digits for the year, excluding FX, and that's a result of strong trends in the Nordics and LatAm. 
Adjusted operating income was up 10% for the quarter and 3% for the year. Programming expenses declined 2% in the fourth quarter given the comparison to last year's programming charges. 
Excluding the charges from both periods and the benefit from reduced amortization this year, programming costs were up double digits in the quarter and the year. That's a result of our continued investments in original programming, including new series like Westworld, Divorce, The Night Of and Insecure. 
So we continue to make progress in our strategic initiatives in 2016, and we have a lot of momentum on the content side. With global demand for HBO's distinctive premium content only growing and subscription revenue trends improving, we're confident HBO can deliver healthy growth for years to come. 
Now looking at Warner Bros., where our theatrical business continues to perform exceptionally well, thanks to our franchise-led film slate. And that resulted in significant profit growth including record adjusted operating income for both the quarter and the year. 
Coming into the year, we plan for theatrical to be the primary driver at Warner's, and that's exactly what played out. Our 2 DC movies and first Fantastic Beasts installment had a very strong diverse slate that drove high single digit growth in theatrical revenues in 2016, and we more than doubled theatrical profits, making this our most profitable film slate in close to a decade. 
The success of the film slate is also contributing to healthy growth in our consumer products business, where revenue increased close to 40% last year. we're already benefiting from the new strategy we put in place and think we have a big opportunity to keep growing our consumer products business over the next few years. 
In TV, we had difficult comparisons on the licensing side, but total revenues were up in the quarter and for the year, mainly due to double-digit growth and initial telecast revenue. That's a result of increased production reflecting Warner's continued expansion as the cable, premium and SVOD production. 
Additionally, we continue to benefit from strong international licensing demand for Warner's TV content. 
As we discussed, we also had difficult comparisons in gaming after record results in 2015 and no franchise console releases last year. So as expected, revenues declined significantly. 
Looking to 2017, we have a strong lineup anchored by 2 franchise consoler releases and several mobile games, so we are set up for a great year in games. 
Across theatrical and TV, home entertainment revenues were down double digits for the year primarily due to fewer releases and a softer home video release schedule. But revenue did grow starting in the second half of 2016 as our franchise title starts to move into the home entertainment window. 
We also remain encouraged by EST, which was up double digits for the year, and digital now represents about half of our home entertainment profit. 
So we're encouraged as we head into 2017, where we expect to grow both home entertainment revenue and profit. 
Overall, Warner Bros. had another terrific year, thanks to great execution of it strategy focused on monetizing key global franchises across all its businesses. And with a tremendous multi-year film slate, healthy trends -- trends in the TV business and upcoming franchise games releases, Warner is positioned to deliver strong growth in its operating income in 2017 and beyond. 
Turning to the next slide, we also had a great year for free cash flow, which increased 22% to a record $4.4 billion. So we converted 94% of our earnings into cash, continuing our strong track record of conversion. We benefited from a strong growth in adjusted operating income as well as lower cash taxes related to the tax accounting change I mentioned earlier. 
Looking to 2017, while we certainly have difficult comparisons especially in our cash taxes, we expect strong conversion and another year of healthy free cash flow. 
Moving on to our balance sheet. We ended 2016 with $22.8 billion of net debt. That's up from 2015 mainly due to our share repurchases in dividends. It also reflects about $1 billion in debt reduction premiums and costs associated with our tender offers in December. We spent about $800 million on M&A for the year, largely related to the investment in Hulu we made in August. So we ended the year right around our leverage target of 2.75x, and with share repurchase discontinued, we continue to expect our net leverage ratio to decline as we progress through 2017. 
So on the whole, we had a great year in 2016, and we believe we're set up for strong 2017, and I'll touch on some of the key items for the year ahead. 
Starting at Turner. We anticipate solid double-digit domestic subscriber subscription revenue growth as we continue to benefit from our affiliate renewal. 
At the same time, as we plan for, we expect programming cost to grow in the double digits, primarily due to the new NBA deal, which will account for approximately $400 million of incremental cost in the first half of 2017. 
And similar to the past few years, Turner remains focused on constraining overhead costs to help fund these investments in great content and new growth opportunities. So that should add us to another year of healthy revenue trend and solid profit growth at Turner. 
At HBO, as I mentioned, we expect subscription revenue growth to be in the high single digits in 2017. That growth should step up through the year as we complete additional affiliate deals, continue to make progress, implementing our new deals and expand digital distribution. The improvement in subscription revenue trends should translate to attractive adjusted operating income growth in 2017. 
At Warner's, we're also poised for healthy growth in adjusted operating income, led by our theatrical and video game businesses. Our franchise slate continues in 2017, with 2 more DC films as well as the LEGO Batman movie, and we expect other businesses like home entertainment, consumer products and TV licensing will benefit from a strong film slate and recent theatrical success. 
I already mentioned our strong gaming slate this year, we also continued to see healthy demand in our TV business and expect another year of solid results as we further expand production. we're positioned to deliver attractive financial results at all of our businesses, and that's reflected in our expectation for 2017 adjusted operating income growth to be in the high single digits. 
Given the NBA deal cost in the first half, the timing of improvement in HBO sub-revenue trends and the cadence of the film and game slate at Warner Bros., at this point, we anticipate that growth will be heavily weighted to the second half of the year. 
Overall, we're very pleased about how we executing across the company and the progress we're making on key initiatives, and we expect to deliver healthy growth in 2017 even as we continue to make important investments in high-quality video content and a new business models that should position us for sustained attractive growth trends well into the future. 
With that, let me turn it back to Jessica to start the Q&A.

Based on what you seeing or expecting, can you update us on your view to what extent you think that will be incremental to the ecosystem and do you think that will be clear by the end of this year, or is that more of a multi-year story in terms of playing out?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll start and go to John. Of course, there's a lot of them that have different price points as we all know. There is also a fair degree of variation in the reach of some of its virtual MVPDs in terms of sub-basis and platforms. So all that is very health
componenttext: I'll start and go to John. Of course, there's a lot of them that have different price points as we all know. There is also a fair degree of variation in the reach of some of its virtual MVPDs in terms of sub-basis and platforms. So all that is very healthy development as we've been predicting yet new entrants coming in all the time, Amazon, Hulu, et cetera. Given the range of all of these things, I think it's safe to say that what's going to have to is invigorate consumer interest everywhere in watching networks on demand, watching them on the go, in mobile devices and the whole range of offerings, which is what we all like to see. And what that's doing is fueling production, increases in production spending across the network industry. So terrific and of course, Warner's has the biggest a supplier to all networks is part of that. I think it's too early to say if you're asking for timing what the relative size of the virtual MVPDs sub growth is, let's say, in '17 versus what the continued slope of the at home ecosystem, subaccount turns out to be. So I don't have a specific answer for that. And John, let me turn it to you quick pressure on you on that one.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I don't have a lot to answer that, but I would say that our outlook doesn't assume a material benefit this year from virtual MVPDs, so that's important when you think about the guidance we've given for subscription revenues. But certainly, ther
componenttext: Yes, look, I don't have a lot to answer that, but I would say that our outlook doesn't assume a material benefit this year from virtual MVPDs, so that's important when you think about the guidance we've given for subscription revenues. But certainly, there's an opportunity for that between DIRECTV now, Sling, and [indiscernible], each of them have really started to gain traction very recently proving that there is consumer demand for smaller video packages with top networks at low prices. I think if you aggregate the number of subscribers for the 3, we're approaching 2 million now in the United States. At new OTT offerings can combine attractive pricing and packaging with great on demand content, better interfaces and easier navigation, we think that we can attract new subs into the ecosystem, and importantly, we take a lot of these subs and not cannibalizing existing subscribers. So that's a great opportunity for Turner to take share since we're in all the major virtual MVPDs that have launched to date, and we expect to be in those [indiscernible] with wide consumer appeal.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Two topics. First on HBO, the 2 million domestic over-the-top subs is an impressive number. But to your point, it doesn't seem to be additive yet and you're focused on subscriber growth next year. Can you talk a little more detail about, how in your reneg
componenttext: Two topics. First on HBO, the 2 million domestic over-the-top subs is an impressive number. But to your point, it doesn't seem to be additive yet and you're focused on subscriber growth next year. Can you talk a little more detail about, how in your renegotiations, you're able to move to the subscriber growth at your anticipating? Anything to help us on the mechanics, that would be great. And then second, you have made some big investments in basketball. We've seen weakness in ratings at football over the past year, and that's caused some concern about the sports rates. Can you just tell us what you're seeing in basketball and why you feel --optimistic about the value of those contracts?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Mike, it's Richard. Thank you for your question. The deals that we've completed already, I think, are very indicative of why we're so encouraged and why we're looking optimistically and confidently to sub-revenue acceleration in the second half of the yea
componenttext: Mike, it's Richard. Thank you for your question. The deals that we've completed already, I think, are very indicative of why we're so encouraged and why we're looking optimistically and confidently to sub-revenue acceleration in the second half of the year. Look, the blended penetration on the 2 deals that we completed is less than 50% of what the acquired companies penetration is. And we've built incentives into those deals to drive that blended penetration up not only to where the acquired companies are, which are in the high 30s, low-40s, but beyond that. So as we look forward with those partners, the nature of the packaging, the nature of the marketing mix is very comfortable that we're going to see that sub-acceleration, number one. Number two, in a couple deals that we have remaining, I think, they, too, are going to see the opportunity before them integral penetration given where they are now in some of our higher-performing affiliates, I think there's an opportunity to go even further. So we like the deals that we've completed. We'll finish the rest of our deals in the coming months. And I would say about our OTT business, it's very, very dynamic. It's actually 3x of the number that we reported at the end of '15. And actually I think that shows that only the robust demand for HBO, but the opportunity we have out there, but also the traditional ecosystem, but outside of it. So we're looking very confident later this year. These deals takes time, and integration takes time and one of our major deals, they're just beginning to put us into the packaging that we've codified into the deal at the end of this month. And so that's really what the lag is, but it will kick in, in the second half of the year.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Jon, do the basketball.
componenttext: Jon, do the basketball.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mike, listen, I feel really confident in the sports that we're in. And if you look across the industry, ratings, in general, have improved recently as we move past the election that we've seen better match ups in more competitive games. So I think
componenttext: Yes. So Mike, listen, I feel really confident in the sports that we're in. And if you look across the industry, ratings, in general, have improved recently as we move past the election that we've seen better match ups in more competitive games. So I think that in the case the declines that we recurring back in the summer and early fall are not really necessarily indicative of a secular trend and we're seeing very strong advertiser demand for both the NBA and the NCAA Men's Basketball Championship. So we continue to feel really good about our premium sports properties. But just to amplify one more thing, you can't forget about the importance of match ups and competitive games. And when we look at the season, whether it's Cleveland versus Golden State or Oklahoma versus the Clippers or the Lakers versus Portland, those games outperformed extremely well with us growing year-over-year. So I think we're going to continue to hope for competitive games, but we love the advertiser demand, and we are optimistic that we're going to be able to continue to grow our ratings for these properties.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Vasily Karasyov with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Vasily Karasyov with CLSA.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: My question is with Kevin. Kevin, you had a fantastic couple of years at Warner Bros., but if one was to look forward, you're already #1 supplier in TV yet the international box office which fuel growth for many in the past decade is not growing anymore a
componenttext: My question is with Kevin. Kevin, you had a fantastic couple of years at Warner Bros., but if one was to look forward, you're already #1 supplier in TV yet the international box office which fuel growth for many in the past decade is not growing anymore as fast. Games come and go. What gives you confidence that you can continue to deliver growth from this very high base at this point? Can you just give us an idea what the drivers are maybe a little longer term than '17. What Howard outline?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you for the question. I think that as Howard mentioned, both for '17 and beyond, we still believe that there's growth in that theatrical business. Our franchise strategy is off to a great start. I think we're going to continue that in '17 whe
componenttext: Great. Thank you for the question. I think that as Howard mentioned, both for '17 and beyond, we still believe that there's growth in that theatrical business. Our franchise strategy is off to a great start. I think we're going to continue that in '17 when we look at what we have in '18 and '19, and we feel very good about it. We also feel that we can still grow in television. And while the growth will occur primarily in broadcast where we've been #1 for a long time, we do feel there are opportunities in premium, in pay, in cable. And I feel really good about the fact that we did Westworld with HBO later this year, and Animal Kingdom with John, and we had some really big hits for Netflix with Floor House and Gilmore Girls as well. So that is a business that we think we can grow and continue to grow. Games, again, a business while it's lumpy, we feel we can create more sustainable pipeline as we get more to scale there on the console side. We have 2 big console games this year in its our goal to be able to put out a more consistent path of those games but also grow mobile which doesn't have that lumpiness. So if you look at those 3 big drivers in the content side, that creates opportunities for consumer products. And geography-wise, we think there's a big opportunity in China, we continue to develop a SVOD service that's doing very well with our partner Tencent, and we also believe that our partnership to create local language content as well as export content into China is going to create the big growth opportunity for the company in the coming years. So we think that we feel good about '17, and more importantly, we feel about the growth trajectory going forward.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was talking to Jeff about this yesterday. I think that we're making a lot of progress because part of the reason that's driving us is consumers. And the economics of the film business because I think what you're seeing is, we talk a lot about these fran
componenttext: I was talking to Jeff about this yesterday. I think that we're making a lot of progress because part of the reason that's driving us is consumers. And the economics of the film business because I think what you're seeing is, we talk a lot about these franchises, but the middle of the market in the theatrical business is that an extremely tough, and we do think that having products like this that are giving movies to consumers want them earlier in the home is a big opportunity. So we've been aggressively working with exhibitors to talk about models that will grow the market versus cannibalize the market, and we think that we're making a lot of progress on that end because ultimately, it's not really about business model per se, but it's really about giving consumers what they want because if we don't give it to them, they're going to go to the pirated version. So it's very high on our list and I think that it has the potential to change some of the economics, some of the films dramas that we're having problems with right now on the theatrical side, which is really important for a company like ours that creates a really broad slate every year.

componenttext: Oh, no, I haven't asked it. And Richard, it sounds like you HBO's OTC business has accelerated quite a bit. headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're thrilled with it. It accelerated very quickly and I think it shows what we've said all along, which is the more opportunities we have to distribute HBO to a multitude of different distribution services and give our consumer the option to get i
componenttext: Sure. We're thrilled with it. It accelerated very quickly and I think it shows what we've said all along, which is the more opportunities we have to distribute HBO to a multitude of different distribution services and give our consumer the option to get it, however and wherever they want, the better it is for our brand. So they've been a terrific new partner, built the other digital partners that you will see announced in the coming weeks and months, and that's why we're so optimistic not only about our traditional business, but about our OTT business as well.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Two questions please. First on Warner Bros., Kevin, given the rapid demand that we've seen in original content demand for TV series, it's clearly been obvious the big benefit for Warner Bros. But further digging into that a bit further beyond just having
componenttext: Two questions please. First on Warner Bros., Kevin, given the rapid demand that we've seen in original content demand for TV series, it's clearly been obvious the big benefit for Warner Bros. But further digging into that a bit further beyond just having higher demand, we're hearing that the terms of the come much more favorable to the producers of these TV series in terms of guaranteed pickup of entire series or better pricing and such. Is that a real notable change in the sense are you seeing more like the chatter or you're actually seeing real benefits from that sort of shift in leverage to the studio side?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think there's a shift in leverage in the high-quality shows that really breakout. And the bifurcation that we're seeing on the theatrical side where a disproportionate share of the revenue is going for the bigger movies, these franchise movies are takin
componenttext: I think there's a shift in leverage in the high-quality shows that really breakout. And the bifurcation that we're seeing on the theatrical side where a disproportionate share of the revenue is going for the bigger movies, these franchise movies are taking a bigger and bigger share. But the big television shows like Westworld that breakout are more valuable whenever because there's more -- original content being out there but there's less things as result because there's more competition for things that really breakout. And so when you have those, and you have AAA talent who typically garner that kind of attention, I think it is more valuable and there is a little bit more leverage on that side.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick question on Turner, if I can. I think you guys have previously said, if I remember correctly, that CNN should have record profitability in 2017. And I guess, with such the news trends the short better sustain, which is obviously good
componenttext: And then just a quick question on Turner, if I can. I think you guys have previously said, if I remember correctly, that CNN should have record profitability in 2017. And I guess, with such the news trends the short better sustain, which is obviously good news for viewership because of the new administration all the chaos there, can cost really come down, I guess, significantly this year? Just any color on that would be great.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, CNN has started the year with a continuing amount of significant momentum that it took outside of last year. As Jeff said, it's the most-watched year ever in the history of CNN closer to FOX news and it has been 8 years and has the greatest advantag
componenttext: Well, CNN has started the year with a continuing amount of significant momentum that it took outside of last year. As Jeff said, it's the most-watched year ever in the history of CNN closer to FOX news and it has been 8 years and has the greatest advantage over MS NBC since 2009. And the strategy this year, we fully expect that linear ratings for the entire year are not going to be able to stay at last year's record levels, so we could have some difficult advertising comps. But CNN still has great momentum, thanks to its strategy, which is multipronged.   It's going in on -- it's going all the way in our covering big stories. It's adding originals. There'll be more hours of originals this year than in the past which brings younger viewers to the networking and usually garners big audiences, and it's investing in digital, which we expect is going to keep growing. It's been growing, add revenue double digits digital now represents 25% of all CNN's overall ad revenue. And last year had its best year overtaking Yahoo! news. So I think CNN is positioned for another record year of profit growth in 2017. We're highly confident that we're going to be able to achieve that and that's going to be led by a healthy increase in affiliate revenues and absolutely lower election-related expenses.

componenttext: Jeff, just one question on BAMTech.  Recently, you did present to walk away from BAMTech and focus energy with NBC. Given the focus on digital distribution, just what understand the background behind that. And Howard, just one question on HBO. I think this quarter again some of the programming amortization lifetime was changed. I think this was second quarter over the last year. So just wanted to understand the thought process behind that.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's Richard. Let me answer your BAMTech question. First of all, our deal with BAM goes through the end of this, so we're still working very closely with them. We, obviously, partnered with them to help launch HBO NOW, but at the same time, we're parallel
componenttext: It's Richard. Let me answer your BAMTech question. First of all, our deal with BAM goes through the end of this, so we're still working very closely with them. We, obviously, partnered with them to help launch HBO NOW, but at the same time, we're parallel processing building our own tech deck, which I will remind you was in place and enabled us to launch HBO GO. So we've only had it in mind that we would create the ability to blend the tax we're going now, build one mobile platform and have own capacity to launch the new service all over the world. That's what we've done. They've been absolutely enhanced part of our strategy, and we'll continue to work with them I expect over the years, but we also are going to move forward doing it on our own.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

componenttext: Let me just add, it's Jeff, before Howard get to [indiscernible].  John, you got iStreamPlanet, you have FilmStruck, we have platforms like that across the company and AT&T has it also. So bear that in mind as you think about the essentially the building capabilities across the company to deliver direct-to-consumer, a variety of products, SVOD platforms and other clients, direct consumer platforms.

componenttext: And right now, a lot of the technology stocks that you're referring to has complementary capabilities some of that are with live streaming, some of that are with VOD, some have customer care capabilities and the goal would be for us to work more collaboratively over time to rationalize the overall technology footprint. And as you said, really excited to see how AT&T can help supercharge that.

componenttext: And the amortization, back in the second quarter, we did make a change that amortization truly a reflection of how our program is being used, particularly with a lot of On Demand and HBO GO, the programming is -- it does have a longer life. And so we did make an adjustment. But just to be clear, we feel significantly accelerated as it was before with the vast majority of the costs are incurred upfront. But we did have a benefit -- most of the benefit by the way, came in the second quarter where we made a change. We did have about $20 million of benefit in the fourth quarter. And as we look ahead to next year, we don't see any net benefit from that as we look ahead to 2017.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

componenttext: The next question is from the line of Bryan Kraft with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a couple questions on HBO. I guess, first, how are you thinking about using the incremental margin that will be generated by the acceleration in affiliate growth? Are you thinking of reinvesting it to expand the content slate marketing, dr
componenttext: I wanted to ask a couple questions on HBO. I guess, first, how are you thinking about using the incremental margin that will be generated by the acceleration in affiliate growth? Are you thinking of reinvesting it to expand the content slate marketing, drive more sub growth or will we see some of that flow to the bottom line and expand margins? And then also just wanted to ask if you could comment just on the behavior that you've seen in terms of churn, obviously, around a big content releases like [indiscernible] or Westworld, you're going to see higher gross adds up. And just curious if you can comment on what you've seen after people have consumed those series, [indiscernible].

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me do the second first. On churn, particularly in the last few months, we've seen the lowest churn really since the beginning of introducing HBO NOW in our OTT product. That I think as a result of two things. Number one is our subscriber base age
componenttext: Yes, let me do the second first. On churn, particularly in the last few months, we've seen the lowest churn really since the beginning of introducing HBO NOW in our OTT product. That I think as a result of two things. Number one is our subscriber base ages, there's, of course, less churn. And number two,, I think it's speaks to the quality of the content and the range of the content. I think it's important to remember when you look at the usage on digital platforms and on demand, you see the usage going across a wide range of categories. It's not just Westworld and Game of Thrones and The Night Of, it's comedies, it's late night, it's documentaries, it's sports program, it's important to punch week that the use of HBO program is across off wide range, and we're in the business, of course, of curating great content. So we're very encouraged by what we've seen on churn. Your question about investment, yes, we are going to take this margins, and we're going to invest a lot of it in what we do for a living, which is trying to make the best content and curate the best content across a lot of different genres of programming. And the exciting thing is the amount of talent that continues to come to the door with new projects literally on a weekly basis gives us no shortage in fact gives us better originals to choose from. And we're very excited about the announcements that you'll see in the coming weeks for 2018 and the investment that we're going to make robustly in programming speaks to, I think, the best of the brand.

componenttext: I want to throw my head in the ring for tickets as well. So, Kevin, is there a meaningful incremental revenue opportunity for in-season stacking rights, or is that have been captured already? And since it's new year, any evolution that we should expect in SVOD licensing strategy, especially since Time Warner obviously last year joined Hulu as a minority shareholder? And for Jeff, there's been a lot of discussion on over the top and direct-to-consumer on this call and others, in media. I was curious, the look at the TV network business as ultimately continuing to be original business or developing into a global network business? And the reason I asked is there's an argument that TV networks are going global and direct-to-consumer, those economics will be superior more sustainable and Netflix and Amazon and FOX are headed there quickly. You gets in and globally but many of your other networks from regional. So just curious how do you see the market place is evolving? What it might mean if anything, for Time Warner in that regard?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the stock award, we think we're confident that we've been able to stocking rates agreement with everyone. And all the networks that we do business with will have capability to be able to offer a range of product with stacking rights because we think it
componenttext: On the stock award, we think we're confident that we've been able to stocking rates agreement with everyone. And all the networks that we do business with will have capability to be able to offer a range of product with stacking rights because we think it's great for the consumer, and you're looking at what the viewing trends are might be to be able to do that. As it relates to any change in the way that we kind of view SVOD and licensing strategy, I think that we continue to look at it on a product-by-product basis, and we continue to evaluate it, and we're going to continue doing that. But the marketplace is evolving, both domestically and internationally. And I think that you're going to continue to see everyone kind of look at and evaluate each piece of content going forward.

componenttext: So I think you're asking about national networks and SVOD services across the United States versus global, across 7 billion people, was that what you're asking?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was asking if you think the world is headed that way and if there is any implication for Time Warner?
componenttext: Yes, I was asking if you think the world is headed that way and if there is any implication for Time Warner?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, yes. The world is heading -- as we all know, towards more global access by people to a rate at a given show or a given network. And as you see the development of that, I know you are referencing some brands that started in the tech world. If y
componenttext: Okay, well, yes. The world is heading -- as we all know, towards more global access by people to a rate at a given show or a given network. And as you see the development of that, I know you are referencing some brands that started in the tech world. If you think of something like either CNN or HBO, and then you are going to expand that half to other networks, both things like CNN or HBO are global brands that got global distribution now. What we've been doing over the years is we've essentially try to capitalize on these SVOD and linear network opportunities going global in terms of territory. And going digital in terms of VOD across platforms and not just TV, but mobile devices. The bulk of people in India or Brazil are watching differently in different device setups than say those in Western Europe or the United States. So we've been pursuing essentially that strategy of distribution for our networks that optimizes the reach of whatever distribution is in place. If you look at -- is orders of combination, HBO is an easy way to describe it because it started VOD, and it started more global distribution as did CNN. So we've got places where HBO is over the top direct as a network. We just launched a few in Western Europe, Spain, we are launching in Latin America, we have things in Eastern Europe like that. We also have HBO in Western Europe licensed into other SVOD like Sky and other sorts of platforms if they have superior reach and can therefore, get our programming, which is usually branded as HBO neighborhood programming. and if then creates a choice as time goes on of whether we decide to move to direct network full schedule or whether we continue to license to optimize value of that network name and the programming associated with it. You've got examples of Turner doing that at FilmStruck. You've got examples of Warner doing it in China, where we're the second largest SVOD service in China?

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Time Warner Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: And HBO is right along side of that, licensed into the service. So yes, it's, of course, everybody did have programming and that can support a network. We'll try to create optimal reach either for the shows of the network and to the extent you can fill it
componenttext: And HBO is right along side of that, licensed into the service. So yes, it's, of course, everybody did have programming and that can support a network. We'll try to create optimal reach either for the shows of the network and to the extent you can fill it out to a full network, that's a valuable asset. And we're moving in that direction where we can, and we're moving to supply those networks that have the reach and can collect the money for us where those conditions don't apply.
